# Ring of Fire

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For other uses, see [Ring of Fire
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Ring_of_Fire_\(disambiguation\) "Ring of Fire
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Pacific_Ring_of_Fire.svg/310px-
Pacific_Ring_of_Fire.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Pacific_Ring_of_Fire.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Pacific_Ring_of_Fire.svg "Enlarge")

The Pacific Ring of Fire

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Plates_tect2_en.svg/310px-
Plates_tect2_en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Plates_tect2_en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Plates_tect2_en.svg "Enlarge")

Tectonic plates of the world

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/EQs_8_plus_since_1900.png/310px-
EQs_8_plus_since_1900.png)](/wiki/File:EQs_8_plus_since_1900.png)

[](/wiki/File:EQs_8_plus_since_1900.png "Enlarge")

Great (magnitude 8.0+) earthquakes 1900–2017, with the majority positioned
along the Ring of Fire

The **Ring of Fire** is a major area in the [basin](/wiki/Ocean_basin "Ocean
basin") of the [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") where many
[earthquakes](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake") and [volcanic
eruptions](/wiki/Types_of_volcanic_eruptions "Types of volcanic eruptions")
occur. In a 40,000 km (25,000 mi) horseshoe shape, it is associated with a
nearly continuous series of [oceanic trenches](/wiki/Oceanic_trench "Oceanic
trench"), [volcanic arcs](/wiki/Volcanic_arc "Volcanic arc"), and [volcanic
belts](/wiki/Volcanic_belt "Volcanic belt") and plate movements. It has 452
[volcanoes](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") (more than 75% of the world's active and
[dormant volcanoes](/wiki/Dormant_volcano "Dormant volcano")).[1] The Ring of
Fire is sometimes called the **circum-Pacific belt**.

About 90%[2] of the world's earthquakes and 81%[3] of the world's largest
earthquakes occur along the Ring of Fire.[4][5] All but three of the world's
25 largest volcanic eruptions of the last 11,700 years occurred at volcanoes
in the Ring of Fire.[6] The Ring of Fire is a direct result of [plate
tectonics](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics"): the movement and
collisions of [lithospheric](/wiki/Lithosphere "Lithosphere") plates,[7]
especially [subduction](/wiki/Subduction "Subduction") in the northern
portion. The southern portion is more complex, with a number of smaller
tectonic plates in collision with the Pacific plate from the [Mariana
Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands"), the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"),
[Bougainville](/wiki/Bougainville_Island "Bougainville Island"),
[Tonga](/wiki/Tonga "Tonga"), and [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand").

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

The presence of a belt of volcanic activity surrounding the Pacific Ocean was
observed in the 19th century. "They [the Japanese Islands] are in the line of
that immense circle of volcanic development which surrounds the shores of the
Pacific from Tierra del Fuego around to the Moluccas." (Matthew Perry,
_Narrative of the Expedition of an American Squadron to the China Seas and
Japan, 1852-54,_ Introduction, Section I, "Name, Extent, and Geography")

About 90%[2] of the world's earthquakes and 81%[3] of the world's largest
earthquakes occur along the Ring of Fire. The next most seismically active
region (5–6% of earthquakes and 17% of the world's largest earthquakes) is the
[Alpide belt](/wiki/Alpide_belt "Alpide belt"), which extends from
[Java](/wiki/Java_\(island\) "Java \(island\)") to the northern [Atlantic
Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") via the
[Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas") and southern Europe.[4][5]

All but three of the world's 25 largest volcanic eruptions of the last 11,700
years occurred at volcanoes in the Ring of Fire.[6]

The famous and very active [San Andreas Fault](/wiki/San_Andreas_Fault "San
Andreas Fault") zone of [California](/wiki/California "California") is a
[transform fault](/wiki/Transform_fault "Transform fault") which offsets a
portion of the [East Pacific Rise](/wiki/East_Pacific_Rise "East Pacific
Rise") under southwestern United States and Mexico; the motion of the fault
generates numerous small earthquakes, at multiple times a day, most of which
are too small to be felt.[8][9]

The active [Queen Charlotte Fault](/wiki/Queen_Charlotte_Fault "Queen
Charlotte Fault") on the west coast of the [Haida Gwaii](/wiki/Haida_Gwaii
"Haida Gwaii"), [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia"),
has generated three large earthquakes during the 20th century: a
[magnitude](/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale "Richter magnitude scale") 7 event
in 1929; a magnitude 8.1 in 1949 (Canada's largest recorded earthquake); and a
magnitude 7.4 in 1970.[10]

## Cause[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Cause")]

The Ring of Fire is a direct result of [plate tectonics](/wiki/Plate_tectonics
"Plate tectonics"): the movement and collisions of
[lithospheric](/wiki/Lithosphere "Lithosphere") plates.[7] The eastern section
of the ring is the result of the [Nazca Plate](/wiki/Nazca_Plate "Nazca
Plate") and the [Cocos Plate](/wiki/Cocos_Plate "Cocos Plate") being
[subducted](/wiki/Subduction "Subduction") beneath the westward-moving [South
American Plate](/wiki/South_American_Plate "South American Plate"). The Cocos
Plate is being subducted beneath the [Caribbean Plate](/wiki/Caribbean_Plate
"Caribbean Plate"), in [Central America](/wiki/Central_America "Central
America"). A portion of the [Pacific Plate](/wiki/Pacific_Plate "Pacific
Plate") and the small [Juan de Fuca Plate](/wiki/Juan_de_Fuca_Plate "Juan de
Fuca Plate") are being subducted beneath the [North American
Plate](/wiki/North_American_Plate "North American Plate"). Along the northern
portion, the northwestward-moving Pacific plate is being subducted beneath the
[Aleutian Islands](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands") arc. Farther
west, the Pacific plate is being subducted along the [Kamchatka
Peninsula](/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula "Kamchatka Peninsula") arcs on south past
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"). The southern portion is more complex, with a
number of smaller tectonic plates in collision with the Pacific plate from the
[Mariana Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands"), the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"),
[Bougainville](/wiki/Bougainville_Island "Bougainville Island"),
[Tonga](/wiki/Tonga "Tonga"), and [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand"); this portion excludes
[Australia](/wiki/Geography_of_Australia#Geology "Geography of Australia"),
since it lies in the center of its tectonic plate. [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia
"Indonesia") lies between the Ring of Fire along the northeastern islands
adjacent to and including [New Guinea](/wiki/New_Guinea "New Guinea") and the
Alpide belt along the south and west from Sumatra, Java, [Bali](/wiki/Bali
"Bali"), [Flores](/wiki/Flores "Flores"), and [Timor](/wiki/Timor "Timor").

## Andes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Andes")]

Further information: [Andean Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Andean_Volcanic_Belt "Andean
Volcanic Belt")

### Bolivia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Bolivia")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in
Bolivia](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Bolivia "List of volcanoes in Bolivia")

Bolivia hosts numerous active and extinct volcanoes across its territory. The
active volcanoes are located in western Bolivia where they make up the
[Cordillera Occidental](/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental_\(Bolivia\) "Cordillera
Occidental \(Bolivia\)"), the western limit of the [Altiplano](/wiki/Altiplano
"Altiplano") plateau. Many of the active volcanoes are international mountains
shared with [Chile](/wiki/Chile "Chile"). All [Cenozoic](/wiki/Cenozoic
"Cenozoic") volcanoes of Bolivia are part of the [Central Volcanic
Zone](/wiki/Central_Volcanic_Zone "Central Volcanic Zone") (CVZ) of the
[Andean Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Andean_Volcanic_Belt "Andean Volcanic Belt") that
results due to processes involved in the [subduction](/wiki/Subduction
"Subduction") of the [Nazca Plate](/wiki/Nazca_Plate "Nazca Plate") under the
[South American Plate](/wiki/South_American_Plate "South American Plate"). The
Central Volcanic Zone is a major upper [Cenozoic](/wiki/Cenozoic "Cenozoic")
volcanic province.[11] Apart from Andean volcanoes, the [geology of
Bolivia](/wiki/Geology_of_Bolivia "Geology of Bolivia") hosts the remnants of
ancient volcanoes around the [Precambrian](/wiki/Precambrian "Precambrian")
Guaporé Shield in the eastern part of the country.

### Chile[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Chile")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Llaima_eruption2_crop.jpg/220px-
Llaima_eruption2_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Llaima_eruption2_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Llaima_eruption2_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

[Llaima](/wiki/Llaima "Llaima")'s 2008 eruption

Main articles: [List of volcanoes in Chile](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Chile
"List of volcanoes in Chile") and [Volcanology of
Chile](/wiki/Volcanology_of_Chile "Volcanology of Chile")

The volcanoes in Chile are monitored by the [National Geology and Mining
Service](/wiki/National_Geology_and_Mining_Service "National Geology and
Mining Service") (SERNAGEOMIN)[12][13]

Earthquake activity in Chile is related to subduction of the Nazca Plate to
the east. Chile notably holds the record for the [largest
earthquake](/wiki/Largest_earthquakes "Largest earthquakes") ever recorded,
the [1960 Valdivia earthquake](/wiki/1960_Valdivia_earthquake "1960 Valdivia
earthquake"). [Villarrica](/wiki/Villarrica_\(volcano\) "Villarrica
\(volcano\)"), one of Chile's most active volcanoes, rises above [Villarrica
Lake](/wiki/Villarrica_Lake "Villarrica Lake") and the town of
[Villarrica](/wiki/Villarrica,_Chile "Villarrica, Chile"). It is the
westernmost of three large [stratovolcanoes](/wiki/Stratovolcano
"Stratovolcano") that trend perpendicular to the Andean chain. A 6-km-wide
[caldera](/wiki/Caldera "Caldera") formed during the late
[Pleistocene](/wiki/Pleistocene "Pleistocene"), more than 0.9 million years
ago.

A 2-km-wide postglacial caldera is located at the base of the presently
active, dominantly basaltic-to-andesitic cone at the northwest margin of the
Pleistocene caldera. About 25 scoria cones dot Villarica's flanks. [Plinian
eruptions](/wiki/Plinian_eruption "Plinian eruption") and [pyroclastic
flows](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow "Pyroclastic flow") have been produced during
the [Holocene](/wiki/Holocene "Holocene") from this dominantly basaltic
volcano, but historical eruptions have consisted of largely mild-to-moderate
explosive activity with occasional lava effusion. [Lahars](/wiki/Lahar
"Lahar") from the glacier-covered volcanoes have damaged towns on its flanks.

The Llaima Volcano is one of the largest and most active volcanoes in Chile.
It is situated 82 km northeast of [Temuco](/wiki/Temuco,_Chile "Temuco,
Chile") and 663 km southeast of [Santiago](/wiki/Santiago,_Chile "Santiago,
Chile"), within the borders of [Conguillío National
Park](/wiki/Conguill%C3%ADo_National_Park "Conguillío National Park").
Llaima’s activity has been documented since the 17th century, and consists of
several separate episodes of moderate explosive eruptions with occasional lava
flows. The last major eruption occurred in 1994.[14]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Lascar_eruption_2006b_-
_cropped.jpg/220px-Lascar_eruption_2006b_-
_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lascar_eruption_2006b_-_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lascar_eruption_2006b_-_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

Lascar erupting in 2006

Chile has experienced numerous volcanic eruptions from 60 volcanoes, including
Llaima Volcano and the [Chaitén Volcano](/wiki/Chait%C3%A9n_Volcano "Chaitén
Volcano"). More recently, a [magnitude-8.8 earthquake struck central Chile on
February 27, 2010](/wiki/2010_Chile_earthquake "2010 Chile earthquake"), the
Puyehue-Cordón Caulle volcano [erupted in 2011](/wiki/2011_Puyehue-
Cord%C3%B3n_Caulle_eruption "2011 Puyehue-Cordón Caulle eruption"), and a
[M8.2 earthquake struck northern Chile on April 1,
2014](/wiki/2014_Iquique_earthquake "2014 Iquique earthquake"). The main shock
was preceded by a number of moderate to large shocks and was followed by a
large number of moderate to very large aftershocks, including a magnitude-7.6
event on 2 April.[15]

[Lascar](/wiki/Lascar_\(volcano\) "Lascar \(volcano\)") is a stratovolcano, is
the most active volcano of the northern Chilean Andes. The largest eruption of
Lascar took place about 26,500 years ago, and following the eruption of the
Tumbres scoria flow about 9,000 years ago, activity shifted back to the
eastern edifice, where three overlapping craters were formed. Frequent small-
to-moderate explosive eruptions have been recorded from Lascar in historical
time since the mid-19th century, along with periodic larger eruptions that
produced ash and [tephra](/wiki/Tephra "Tephra") fall up to hundreds of
kilometers away from the volcano.[16] The largest eruption of Lascar in recent
history took place in 1993, producing [pyroclastic
flows](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow "Pyroclastic flow") as far as 8.5 km (5 mi)
northwest of the summit and ash fall in [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires
"Buenos Aires"), Argentina,[16] more than 1,600 km (994 mi) to the southeast.
The latest series of eruptions began on 18 April 2006 and was continuing as of
2011.

[Chiliques](/wiki/Chiliques "Chiliques") is a stratovolcano located in the
[Antofagasta Region](/wiki/Antofagasta_Region "Antofagasta Region") of Chile,
immediately north of [Cerro Miscanti](/wiki/Cerro_Miscanti "Cerro Miscanti").
[Laguna Lejía](/wiki/Laguna_Lej%C3%ADa "Laguna Lejía") lies to the north of
the volcano and has been dormant for at least 10,000 years, but is now showing
signs of life. A January 6, 2002, nighttime thermal infrared image from
[ASTER](/wiki/Advanced_Spaceborne_Thermal_Emission_and_Reflection_Radiometer
"Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer") revealed a
hot spot in the summit crater, as well as several others along the upper
flanks of the volcano’s edifice, indicating new volcanic activity. Examination
of an earlier nighttime thermal infrared image from May 24, 2000, showed no
such hot spots.[17]

[Calbuco](/wiki/Calbuco_\(volcano\) "Calbuco \(volcano\)") is a stratovolcano
in southern Chile, located southeast of [Llanquihue
Lake](/wiki/Llanquihue_Lake "Llanquihue Lake") and northwest of [Chapo
Lake](/wiki/Chapo_Lake "Chapo Lake"), in [Los Lagos
Region](/wiki/Los_Lagos_Region "Los Lagos Region"). The volcano and the
surrounding area are protected within [Llanquihue National
Reserve](/wiki/Llanquihue_National_Reserve "Llanquihue National Reserve"). It
is a very explosive [andesite](/wiki/Andesite "Andesite") volcano that
underwent edifice collapse in the late [Pleistocene](/wiki/Pleistocene
"Pleistocene"), producing a volcanic [debris avalanche](/wiki/Debris_avalanche
"Debris avalanche") that reached the lake. At least nine eruptions occurred
since 1837, with the latest one in 1972. One of the largest historical
eruptions in southern Chile took place there in 1893–1894. Violent eruptions
ejected 30-cm bombs to distances of 8 km from the crater, accompanied by
voluminous hot lahars. Strong explosions occurred in April 1917, and a [lava
dome](/wiki/Lava_dome "Lava dome") formed in the crater accompanied by hot
lahars. Another short explosive eruption in January 1929 also included an
apparent pyroclastic flow and a lava flow. The last major eruption of Calbuco,
in 1961, sent ash columns 12–15 km high and produced plumes that dispersed
mainly to the southeast and two lava flows were also emitted. A minor, four-
hour eruption happened on August 26, 1972. Strong fumarolic emission from the
main crater was observed on August 12, 1996.

[Lonquimay](/wiki/Lonquimay_\(volcano\) "Lonquimay \(volcano\)") is a
stratovolocano of late-Pleistocene to dominantly Holocene age, with the shape
of a truncated cone. The cone is largely andesitic, though
[basaltic](/wiki/Basalt "Basalt") and [dacitic](/wiki/Dacite "Dacite") rocks
are present.[18] It is located in [La Araucanía
Region](/wiki/La_Araucan%C3%ADa_Region "La Araucanía Region") of
[Chile](/wiki/Chile "Chile"), immediately southeast of
[Tolhuaca](/wiki/Tolhuaca_\(volcano\) "Tolhuaca \(volcano\)") volcano. [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(stratovolcano\) "Sierra Nevada
\(stratovolcano\)") and Llaima are their neighbors to the south. The snow-
capped volcano lies within the protected area [Malalcahuello-
Nalcas](/wiki/Malalcahuello-Nalcas "Malalcahuello-Nalcas"). The volcano last
erupted in 1988, ending in 1990. The [VEI](/wiki/Volcanic_Explosivity_Index
"Volcanic Explosivity Index") was 3. The eruption was from a flank vent and
involved lava flows and explosive eruptions. Some fatalities occurred.[19]

[Antuco Volcano](/wiki/Antuco_Volcano "Antuco Volcano") is a stratovolocano
located in the [Bío Bío Region](/wiki/B%C3%ADo_B%C3%ADo_Region "Bío Bío
Region") of Chile, near [Sierra Velluda](/wiki/Sierra_Velluda "Sierra
Velluda") and on the shore of [Laguna del Laja](/wiki/Laguna_del_Laja "Laguna
del Laja"), with its last eruption in 1869.

[Villarrica](/wiki/Villarrica_\(volcano\) "Villarrica \(volcano\)") is one of
Chile's most active volcanoes, rising above the [lake](/wiki/Lake_Villarrica
"Lake Villarrica") and [town](/wiki/Villarrica,_Chile "Villarrica, Chile") of
the same name. The volcano is also known as _Rucapillán_ , a
[Mapuche](/wiki/Mapudungun "Mapudungun") word meaning "House of the
[Pillán](/wiki/Pill%C3%A1n "Pillán")". It is the westernmost of three large
stratovolcanoes that trend perpendicular to the Andes along the [Gastre
Fault](/wiki/Gastre_Fault_Zone "Gastre Fault Zone"). Villarrica, along with
[Quetrupillán](/wiki/Quetrupill%C3%A1n "Quetrupillán") and the Chilean portion
of [Lanín](/wiki/Lan%C3%ADn "Lanín"), are protected within [Villarrica
National Park](/wiki/Villarrica_National_Park "Villarrica National Park").
Ascents of the volcano are popular with several guided ascents reaching the
top during summer.

Villarrica, with its lava of basaltic-andesitic composition, is one of only
five volcanoes worldwide known to have an active [lava lake](/wiki/Lava_lake
"Lava lake") within its crater. The volcano usually generates [strombolian
eruptions](/wiki/Strombolian_eruption "Strombolian eruption"), with ejection
of [incandescent](/wiki/Incandescent "Incandescent") pyroclasts and lava
flows. Melting of snow and [glacier ice](/wiki/Glacier "Glacier"), as well as
rainfall, often causes massive lahars, such as during the eruptions of 1964
and 1971.[20]

### Ecuador[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Ecuador")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in
Ecuador](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Ecuador "List of volcanoes in Ecuador")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/19991102_Tung_large.jpg/220px-19991102_Tung_large.jpg)](/wiki/File:19991102_Tung_large.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:19991102_Tung_large.jpg "Enlarge")

Tungurahua spews hot lava and ash at night (1999).

In Ecuador, [EPN](/wiki/National_Polytechnic_School_\(Ecuador\) "National
Polytechnic School \(Ecuador\)") monitors the volcanic activity in this andean
nation.

[Cotopaxi](/wiki/Cotopaxi "Cotopaxi") is a stratovolcano in the Andes, located
about 50 km (31 mi) south of [Quito](/wiki/Quito "Quito"),
[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador"), [South America](/wiki/South_America "South
America").[21] It is the second-highest summit in the country, reaching a
height of 5,897 m (19,347 ft). Some consider it the world's highest active
volcano,[22] and it is one of Ecuador's most active volcanoes. Since 1738,
Cotopaxi has erupted more than 50 times, resulting in the creation of numerous
valleys formed by mudflows around the volcano.

In October 1999, Pichincha Volcano erupted in Quito and covered the city with
several inches of [ash](/wiki/Volcanic_ash "Volcanic ash"). Prior to that, the
last major eruptions were in 1553[23] and in 1660, when about 30 cm of ash
fell on the city.[24]

At 5,230 m, [Sangay](/wiki/Sangay "Sangay") Volcano[25] is an active
stratovolcano in central Ecuador, and is one of the highest active volcanoes
in the world and one of Ecuador's most active ones, erupting three times in
recorded history. It exhibits mostly [strombolian](/wiki/Strombolian_eruption
"Strombolian eruption") activity; the most recent eruption, which started in
1934, is still going on. Geologically, Sangay marks the southern bound of the
[Northern Volcanic Zone](/wiki/Northern_Volcanic_Zone "Northern Volcanic
Zone"), and its position straddling two major pieces of
[crust](/wiki/Crust_\(geology\) "Crust \(geology\)") accounts for its high
level of activity. Sangay's roughly 500,000-year history is one of
instability; two previous versions of the mountain were destroyed in massive
flank collapses, evidence of which still litters its surroundings today.
Sangay is one of two active volcanoes located within the namesake [Sangay
National Park](/wiki/Sangay_National_Park "Sangay National Park"), the other
being Tungurahua to the north. As such, it has been listed as a
[UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") [World Heritage
Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") since 1983.

[Reventador](/wiki/Reventador "Reventador") is an active stratovolcano which
lies in the eastern Andes of Ecuador. Since 1541, it has erupted over 25
times, with its most recent eruption in 2009,[26] but the largest historical
eruption occurred in 2002. During that eruption, the plume from the volcano
reached a height of 17 km, and pyroclastic flows went up to 7 km from the
cone. On March 30, 2007, the mountain spewed ash again. The ash reached a
height of about two miles (3 km, 11,000 ft).

[Cotopaxi](/wiki/Cotopaxi "Cotopaxi"), outside of [Quito](/wiki/Quito
"Quito"), started activity in April 2015. A large increase in earthquakes
(including harmonic tremors) and [SO2](/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide "Sulfur dioxide")
emissions began. IGPEN reported slight deformation of the edifice, suggesting
an intrusion of magma under the volcano. As of 25 July, the unrest continued,
and the most recent major eruption was an ash and steam eruption that occurred
on August 14 and 15, 2015.[27][28][29][30][31]

### Peru[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Peru")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in Peru](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Peru
"List of volcanoes in Peru")

Volcanoes in Peru are monitored by the Peruvian Geophysical Institute.[32]

[Sabancaya](/wiki/Sabancaya "Sabancaya") is an active 5,976-metre (19,606 ft)
stratovolcano in the Andes of southern [Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru"), about 100
kilometres (62 mi) northwest of [Arequipa](/wiki/Arequipa "Arequipa"). It is
the most active volcano in Peru, with an ongoing eruption that started in
August 2014.

[Ubinas](/wiki/Ubinas "Ubinas") is another active volcano 5,672-metre (18,609
ft) in southern Peru with an ongoing eruption.[33][34] Until 2006, this
stratovolcano had not erupted for about 40 years. On April 23, 2006, Peru
declared a state of emergency in towns near the volcano. On April 28, 2014,
despite a recent decline in earthquakes, Ubinas Volcano erupted an ash plume
on April 28, 2014.[35][36]

## Central
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Central America")]

### Costa Rica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Costa Rica")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in Costa
Rica](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Costa_Rica "List of volcanoes in Costa Rica")

The Volcanological and Seismological Observatory of Costa Rica (OVSICORI) at
the [National University of Costa
Rica](/wiki/National_University_of_Costa_Rica "National University of Costa
Rica"), in Spanish Observatorio Vulcanológico y Sismológico de Costa Rica
(OVSICORI)[37] have a dedicated team in charge of researching and monitoring
the volcanoes, earthquakes, and other tectonic processes in the [Central
America Volcanic Arc](/wiki/Central_America_Volcanic_Arc "Central America
Volcanic Arc"). In 1984, the OVSICORI-A initiated the operation of a
seismographic network designed to monitor seismic and volcanic activity
throughout the national territory. Currently, the seismographic network has an
analog and a digital registration system. The latter enables online analysis
of seismic signals, allowing to expedite the analysis of signals and the study
using modern computerized methods. [Poás Volcano](/wiki/Po%C3%A1s_Volcano
"Poás Volcano") is an active 2,708-metre (8,885 ft) stratovolcano located in
central [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"); it has erupted 39 times
since 1828. On February 25, 2014, a webcam from the OVSICORI captured the
moment a dark cloud exploded about 1,000 feet (300 m) in the air from a
massive crater of the Poás Volcano.[38][39][40]

### Guatemala[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Guatemala")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in
Guatemala](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Guatemala "List of volcanoes in
Guatemala")

In 1902, the [Santa Maria Volcano](/wiki/Santa_Maria_Volcano "Santa Maria
Volcano") erupted violently in [Guatemala](/wiki/Guatemala "Guatemala"), with
the largest explosions occurring over two days, ejecting an estimated 5.5 km3
(1.3 mi3) of magma. The eruption was one of the largest of the 20th century,
only slightly less in magnitude to that of Mount Pinatubo in 1991. The
eruption had a [volcanic explosivity index](/wiki/Volcanic_explosivity_index
"Volcanic explosivity index") of 6. Today Santiaguito is one of the world's
most active
volcanoes.[[1]](http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/vwdocs/volc_images/south_america/guat/santa_maria.html)
[[2]](https://web.archive.org/web/20141220215241/https://www.geophysics.zmaw.de/?id=318)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Volcan-Santiaguito-
Quetzaltenango-Guatemala.jpg/220px-Volcan-Santiaguito-Quetzaltenango-
Guatemala.jpg)](/wiki/File:Volcan-Santiaguito-Quetzaltenango-Guatemala.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Volcan-Santiaguito-Quetzaltenango-Guatemala.jpg "Enlarge")

Santiaguito Volcano, 2003 eruption in Guatemala

## North American
Cordillera[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: North American Cordillera")]

### Mexico[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Mexico")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in Mexico](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Mexico
"List of volcanoes in Mexico")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Map_mexico_volcanoes.gif/220px-
Map_mexico_volcanoes.gif)](/wiki/File:Map_mexico_volcanoes.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Map_mexico_volcanoes.gif "Enlarge")

The [Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Trans-Mexican_Volcanic_Belt "Trans-
Mexican Volcanic Belt")

Volcanoes of Mexico are related to subduction of the [Cocos](/wiki/Cocos_Plate
"Cocos Plate") and [Rivera](/wiki/Rivera_Plate "Rivera Plate") plates to the
east, which has produced large, explosive eruptions. Most active volcanoes in
Mexico occur in the [Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Trans-
Mexican_Volcanic_Belt "Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt"), which extends 900
kilometres (559 mi) from west to east across central-southern Mexico. A few
other active volcanoes in northern Mexico are related to [extensional
tectonics](/wiki/Extensional_tectonics "Extensional tectonics") of the [Basin
and Range Province](/wiki/Basin_and_Range_Province "Basin and Range
Province"), which splits the Baja California peninsula from the mainland.[41]
[Popocatépetl](/wiki/Popocat%C3%A9petl "Popocatépetl"), lying in the eastern
half of the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt, is the second-highest peak in Mexico
after the [Pico de Orizaba](/wiki/Pico_de_Orizaba "Pico de Orizaba"). It is
one of the most active volcanoes in Mexico, having had more than 20 major
eruptions since the arrival of the Spanish in 1519. The 1982 eruption of [El
Chichón](/wiki/El_Chich%C3%B3n "El Chichón"), which killed about 2,000 people
who lived near the volcano, created a 1-km-wide caldera that filled with an
acidic crater lake. Prior to 2000, this relatively unknown volcano was heavily
forested and of no greater height than adjacent nonvolcanic peaks.[41]

### United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: United States")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in the United
States](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_the_United_States "List of volcanoes in the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Cascadia_subduction_zone_USGS.png/220px-
Cascadia_subduction_zone_USGS.png)](/wiki/File:Cascadia_subduction_zone_USGS.png)

[](/wiki/File:Cascadia_subduction_zone_USGS.png "Enlarge")

Area of the [Cascadia subduction zone](/wiki/Cascadia_subduction_zone
"Cascadia subduction zone"), including the [Cascade Volcanic
Arc](/wiki/Cascade_Volcanoes "Cascade Volcanoes") (red triangles)

The [United States Geological Survey](/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey
"United States Geological Survey") and the [National Earthquake Information
Center](/wiki/National_Earthquake_Information_Center "National Earthquake
Information Center") (NEIC) are located on the campus of the [University of
South Carolina ](/wiki/University_of_South_Carolina "University of South
Carolina") in [Columbia, South Carolina ](/wiki/Columbia,_South_Carolina
"Columbia, South Carolina"). Both monitor volcanos in the United States; in
Gaffney, South Carolina lies the [Cascade Volcanic
Arc](/wiki/Cascade_Volcanoes "Cascade Volcanoes"). It includes nearly 20 major
volcanoes, among a total of over 4,000 separate volcanic vents including
numerous stratovolcanoes, shield volcanoes, lava domes, and cinder cones,
along with a few isolated examples of rarer volcanic forms such as
[tuyas](/wiki/Tuya "Tuya"). Volcanism in the arc began about 37 million years
ago, but most of the present-day Cascade volcanoes are less than 2,000,000
years old, and the highest peaks are less than 100,000 years old. The arc
formed by the subduction of the [Gorda](/wiki/Gorda_Plate "Gorda Plate") and
[Juan de Fuca](/wiki/Juan_de_Fuca_Plate "Juan de Fuca Plate") plates at the
[Cascadia subduction zone](/wiki/Cascadia_subduction_zone "Cascadia subduction
zone"). This is a 680-mi-long [fault](/wiki/Fault_\(geology\) "Fault
\(geology\)"), running 50 mi (80 km) off the coast of the [Pacific
Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest "Pacific Northwest") from northern
California to [Vancouver Island](/wiki/Vancouver_Island "Vancouver Island"),
British Columbia. The plates move at a relative rate over 0.4 in (10 mm) per
year at a somewhat oblique angle to the subduction zone.

Because of the very large fault area, the Cascadia subduction zone can produce
very large earthquakes, magnitude 9.0 or greater, if rupture occurred over its
whole area. When the "locked" zone stores energy for an earthquake, the
"transition" zone, although somewhat plastic, can rupture. Thermal and
deformation studies indicate that the locked zone is fully locked for 60 km
(about 40 mi) down-dip from the deformation front. Further down-dip, a
transition from fully locked to [aseismic sliding](/wiki/Aseismic_creep
"Aseismic creep") occurs.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Cascade_eruptions_in_the_last_4000_years.png/220px-
Cascade_eruptions_in_the_last_4000_years.png)](/wiki/File:Cascade_eruptions_in_the_last_4000_years.png)

[](/wiki/File:Cascade_eruptions_in_the_last_4000_years.png "Enlarge")

American [Cascade Range](/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") volcano
eruptions in the last 4000 years

Unlike most subduction zones worldwide, no [oceanic
trench](/wiki/Oceanic_trench "Oceanic trench") is present along the
[continental margin](/wiki/Continental_margin "Continental margin") in
[Cascadia](/wiki/Cascadia_subduction_zone "Cascadia subduction zone").
Instead, [terranes](/wiki/Terrane "Terrane") and the [accretionary
wedge](/wiki/Accretionary_wedge "Accretionary wedge") have been lifted up to
form a series of coast ranges and exotic mountains. A high rate of
sedimentation from the outflow of the three major rivers ([Fraser
River](/wiki/Fraser_River "Fraser River"), [Columbia
River](/wiki/Columbia_River "Columbia River"), and [Klamath
River](/wiki/Klamath_River "Klamath River")) which cross the Cascade Range
contributes to further obscuring the presence of a trench. However, in common
with most other subduction zones, the outer margin is slowly being compressed,
similar to a giant [spring](/wiki/Spring_\(device\) "Spring \(device\)"). When
the stored energy is suddenly released by slippage across the fault at
irregular intervals, the Cascadia subduction zone can create very large
earthquakes such as the magnitude-9 [Cascadia earthquake of
1700](/wiki/1700_Cascadia_earthquake "1700 Cascadia earthquake"). Geological
evidence indicates that great earthquakes may have occurred at least seven
times in the last 3,500 years, suggesting a return time of 400 to 600 years.
Also, evidence of accompanying tsunamis with every earthquake is seen, as the
prime reason these earthquakes are known is through "scars" the tsunami left
on the coast, and through [Japanese](/wiki/Japan "Japan") records (tsunami
waves can travel across the Pacific).

The [1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens](/wiki/1980_eruption_of_Mount_St._Helens "1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens") was the most significant to occur in the contiguous 48 U.S. states in
recorded history ([VEI](/wiki/Volcanic_Explosivity_Index "Volcanic Explosivity
Index") = 5, 0.3 cu mi, 1.2 km3 of material erupted), exceeding the
destructive power and volume of material released by the 1915 eruption of
California's [Lassen Peak](/wiki/Lassen_Peak "Lassen Peak"). The eruption was
preceded by a two-month series of earthquakes and steam-venting episodes
caused by an injection of [magma](/wiki/Magma "Magma") at shallow depth below
the mountain that created a huge bulge and a fracture system on [Mount St.
Helens](/wiki/Mount_St._Helens "Mount St. Helens")' north slope. An earthquake
at 8:32 am on May 18, 1980, caused the entire weakened north face to slide
away, suddenly exposing the partly molten, gas- and steam-rich rock in the
volcano to lower pressure. The rock responded by exploding into a very hot mix
of pulverized lava and older rock that sped toward [Spirit
Lake](/wiki/Spirit_Lake_\(Washington\) "Spirit Lake \(Washington\)") so fast
that it quickly passed the avalanching north face.

[Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") is known for its seismic and volcanic
activity, holding the record for the second-largest earthquake in the world,
the [Good Friday earthquake](/wiki/Good_Friday_earthquake "Good Friday
earthquake"), and having more than 50 volcanoes which have erupted since about
1760.[42] Volcanoes can be found not only in the mainland, but also in the
[Aleutian Islands](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands").

The most recent activity in the American portion of the Ring of Fire occurred
in early 2009 when [Mount Redoubt](/wiki/Mount_Redoubt "Mount Redoubt") in
Alaska became active and finally erupted late in the evening of March 22. The
eruption ended in May 2009.

### Canada[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Canada")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Young_volcanoes_of_western_Canada.png/220px-
Young_volcanoes_of_western_Canada.png)](/wiki/File:Young_volcanoes_of_western_Canada.png)

[](/wiki/File:Young_volcanoes_of_western_Canada.png "Enlarge")

Map of young volcanoes in [Western Canada](/wiki/Western_Canada "Western
Canada")

See also: [Volcanism in Canada](/wiki/Volcanism_in_Canada "Volcanism in
Canada")

The Public Safety Geo-science Program at the [Natural Resources
Canada](/wiki/Natural_Resources_Canada "Natural Resources Canada") undertakes
research to support risk reduction from the effects of space weather,
earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanoes, and landslides.[43]

British Columbia and [Yukon](/wiki/Yukon "Yukon") are home to a vast region of
volcanoes and volcanic activity in the Pacific Ring of Fire.[44] Several
mountains in populated areas of British Columbia are [dormant
volcanoes](/wiki/Dormant_volcano "Dormant volcano"). Most of these were active
during the Pleistocene and Holocene epochs. Although none of Canada's
volcanoes are currently erupting, several volcanoes, volcanic fields, and
volcanic centers are considered potentially active.[45] [Hot
springs](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot spring") are at some volcanoes, while 10
volcanoes in British Columbia appear related to seismic activity since 1975,
including: the [Silverthrone Caldera](/wiki/Silverthrone_Caldera "Silverthrone
Caldera"), [Mount Meager massif](/wiki/Mount_Meager_massif "Mount Meager
massif"), [Wells Gray-Clearwater volcanic field](/wiki/Wells_Gray-
Clearwater_volcanic_field "Wells Gray-Clearwater volcanic field"), [Mount
Garibaldi](/wiki/Mount_Garibaldi "Mount Garibaldi"), [Mount Cayley
massif](/wiki/Mount_Cayley_massif "Mount Cayley massif"), [Castle
Rock](/wiki/Castle_Rock_\(volcano\) "Castle Rock \(volcano\)"), [The
Volcano](/wiki/The_Volcano_\(British_Columbia\) "The Volcano \(British
Columbia\)"), [Mount Edziza](/wiki/Mount_Edziza "Mount Edziza"), [Hoodoo
Mountain](/wiki/Hoodoo_Mountain "Hoodoo Mountain"), [Crow
Lagoon](/wiki/Crow_Lagoon "Crow Lagoon"), and [Nazko Cone](/wiki/Nazko_Cone
"Nazko Cone").[46] The volcanoes are grouped into five volcanic belts with
different tectonic settings.

The [Northern Cordilleran Volcanic
Province](/wiki/Northern_Cordilleran_Volcanic_Province "Northern Cordilleran
Volcanic Province") (sometimes known as the Stikine Volcanic Belt) is the most
active volcanic region in Canada. It formed due to extensional cracking,
faulting, and [rifting](/wiki/Rift "Rift") of the North American Plate, as the
Pacific Plate grinds and slides past the [Queen Charlotte
Fault](/wiki/Queen_Charlotte_Fault "Queen Charlotte Fault"), unlike subduction
that produces the volcanoes in Japan, the Philippines, and Indonesia. The
region has Canada's largest volcanoes,[44] much larger than the minor
stratovolcanoes found in the Canadian portion of the [Cascade Volcanic
Arc](/wiki/Garibaldi_Volcanic_Belt "Garibaldi Volcanic Belt").[44] Several
eruptions are known to have occurred within the last 400 years. [Mount
Edziza](/wiki/Mount_Edziza "Mount Edziza") is a huge volcanic complex that
erupted several times in the past several thousand years and has formed
several cinder cones and lava flows. The complex comprises the [Mount Edziza
Plateau](/wiki/Mount_Edziza_Plateau "Mount Edziza Plateau"), a large volcanic
plateau (65 km long and 20 km wide) made of predominantly basaltic lava flows
with four large stratovolcanoes built on top of the plateau. The associated
lava domes and satellite cones were constructed over the past 7.5 million
years during five magmatic cycles beginning with eruption of alkali basalts
and ending with [felsic](/wiki/Felsic "Felsic") and basaltic eruptions as late
as 1,340 years ago. The blocky lava flows still maintain their original forms.
Hoodoo Mountain is a [tuya](/wiki/Tuya "Tuya") in northwestern British
Columbia, which has had several periods of [subglacial
eruptions](/wiki/Subglacial_eruption "Subglacial eruption"). The oldest
eruptions occurred about 100,000 years ago and the most recent about 7000
years ago. Hoodoo Mountain is also considered active, so could erupt in the
future. The nearby [Tseax Cone](/wiki/Tseax_Cone "Tseax Cone") and The Volcano
produced some of Canada's youngest lava flows, about 150 years old.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Mount_Edziza%2C_British_Columbia.jpg/220px-
Mount_Edziza%2C_British_Columbia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Edziza,_British_Columbia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mount_Edziza,_British_Columbia.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mount Edziza](/wiki/Mount_Edziza "Mount Edziza"), a large shield volcano in
northwestern British Columbia

Canada's worst known geophysical disaster came from the Tseax Cone during the
18th century at the southernmost end of the volcanic belt. The eruption
produced a 22.5-km-long lava flow, destroying the [Nisga'a](/wiki/Nisga%27a
"Nisga'a") villages and the death of at least 2000 Nisga'a people by volcanic
gases and poisonous smoke. The [Nass River](/wiki/Nass_River "Nass River")
valley was inundated by the lava flows and contains abundant tree molds and
lava tubes. The event happened at the same time as the arrival of the first
European explorers to penetrate the uncharted coastal waters of northern
British Columbia. Today, the basaltic lava deposits are a draw to tourists and
are part of the [Nisga'a Memorial Lava Beds Provincial
Park](/wiki/Nisga%27a_Memorial_Lava_Beds_Provincial_Park "Nisga'a Memorial
Lava Beds Provincial Park").

The [Garibaldi Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Garibaldi_Volcanic_Belt "Garibaldi
Volcanic Belt") in southwestern British Columbia is the northern extension of
the Cascade Volcanic Arc in the United States (which includes [Mount
Baker](/wiki/Mount_Baker "Mount Baker") and Mount St. Helens) and contains the
most explosive young volcanoes in Canada.[47] It formed as a result of
subduction of the Juan de Fuca Plate (a remnant of the much larger [Farallon
Plate](/wiki/Farallon_Plate "Farallon Plate")) under the North American Plate
along the Cascadia subduction zone.[47] The Garibaldi Volcanic Belt includes
the [Bridge River Cones](/wiki/Bridge_River_Cones "Bridge River Cones"),
[Mount Cayley massif](/wiki/Mount_Cayley_massif "Mount Cayley massif"), [Mount
Fee](/wiki/Mount_Fee "Mount Fee"), [Mount Garibaldi](/wiki/Mount_Garibaldi
"Mount Garibaldi"), [Mount Price](/wiki/Mount_Price_\(British_Columbia\)
"Mount Price \(British Columbia\)"), [Mount Meager
massif](/wiki/Mount_Meager_massif "Mount Meager massif"), the Squamish
Volcanic Field, and more smaller volcanoes. The eruption styles in the belt
range from [effusive](/wiki/Effusive_eruption "Effusive eruption") to
[explosive](/wiki/Explosive_eruption "Explosive eruption"), with compositions
from basalt to [rhyolite](/wiki/Rhyolite "Rhyolite"). Morphologically, centers
include calderas, cinder cones, stratovolcanoes and small isolated lava
masses. Due to repeated continental and alpine glaciations, many of the
volcanic deposits in the belt reflect complex interactions between magma
composition, topography, and changing ice configurations. The most recent
major catastrophic eruption in the Garibaldi Volcanic Belt was an explosive
eruption of the Mount Meager massif about 2,350 years ago. It was similar to
the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens,[47] sending an [ash
column](/wiki/Eruption_column "Eruption column") about 20 km into the
[stratosphere](/wiki/Stratosphere "Stratosphere").[48]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/MountMeagerPlinthCapricorn.jpg/220px-
MountMeagerPlinthCapricorn.jpg)](/wiki/File:MountMeagerPlinthCapricorn.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MountMeagerPlinthCapricorn.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Mount Meager massif](/wiki/Mount_Meager_massif "Mount Meager massif") as
seen from the east near Pemberton, BC: Summits left to right are [Capricorn
Mountain](/wiki/Capricorn_Mountain "Capricorn Mountain"), [Mount
Meager](/wiki/Mount_Meager "Mount Meager"), and [Plinth
Peak](/wiki/Plinth_Peak "Plinth Peak").

The [Chilcotin Group](/wiki/Chilcotin_Group "Chilcotin Group") is a north-
south range of volcanoes in southern British Columbia running parallel to the
Garibaldi Volcanic Belt. The majority of the eruptions in this belt happened
either 6–10 million years ago ([Miocene](/wiki/Miocene "Miocene")) or 2–3
million years ago (Pliocene), although with some slightly more recent
eruptions (in the Pleistocene).[49] It is thought to have formed as a result
of [back-arc extension](/wiki/Back-arc_basin "Back-arc basin") behind the
Cascadia subduction zone.[49] Volcanoes in this belt include [Mount
Noel](/wiki/Mount_Noel "Mount Noel"), the [Clisbako Caldera
Complex](/wiki/Clisbako_Caldera_Complex "Clisbako Caldera Complex"),
[Lightning Peak](/wiki/Lightning_Peak_\(British_Columbia\) "Lightning Peak
\(British Columbia\)"), [Black Dome Mountain](/wiki/Black_Dome_Mountain "Black
Dome Mountain"), and many lava flows.

The [Anahim Volcanic Belt](/wiki/Anahim_Volcanic_Belt "Anahim Volcanic Belt")
is a line of volcanoes stretching from just north of Vancouver Island to near
[Quesnel](/wiki/Quesnel,_British_Columbia "Quesnel, British Columbia"),
British Columbia. These volcanoes were formed 8 to 1 million years ago, and
the Nazko Cone last erupted only 7,200 years ago.[50] The volcanoes generally
get younger moving from the coast to the interior. These volcanoes are thought
to have formed as a result of the North American Plate sliding westward over a
small [hotspot](/wiki/Hotspot_\(geology\) "Hotspot \(geology\)"), called the
[Anahim hotspot](/wiki/Anahim_hotspot "Anahim hotspot").[50] The hotspot is
considered similar to the one feeding the [Hawaiian
Islands](/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands "Hawaiian Islands").[50] The belt is defined
by three large [shield volcanoes](/wiki/Shield_volcano "Shield volcano")
([Rainbow](/wiki/Rainbow_Range_\(Coast_Mountains\) "Rainbow Range \(Coast
Mountains\)"), [Ilgachuz](/wiki/Ilgachuz_Range "Ilgachuz Range") and the
[Itcha Ranges](/wiki/Itcha_Range "Itcha Range")) and 37
[Quaternary](/wiki/Quaternary "Quaternary") basalt centers.

Eruptions of basaltic to rhyolitic volcanoes and [hypabyssal](/wiki/Hypabyssal
"Hypabyssal") rocks of the [Alert Bay Volcanic
Belt](/wiki/Alert_Bay_Volcanic_Belt "Alert Bay Volcanic Belt") in northern
Vancouver Island are probably linked with the subducted margin flanked by the
[Explorer](/wiki/Explorer_Plate "Explorer Plate") and Juan de Fuca Plates at
the Cascadia subduction zone. It appears to have been active during the
Pliocene and Pleistocene. However, no Holocene eruptions are known, and
volcanic activity in the belt has likely ceased.

## Russia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Russia")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in Russia](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Russia
"List of volcanoes in Russia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Avachinsky_Volcano.jpg/220px-
Avachinsky_Volcano.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avachinsky_Volcano.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Avachinsky_Volcano.jpg "Enlarge")

[Avachinsky](/wiki/Avachinsky "Avachinsky"), an active volcano on the
Kamchatka Peninsula.

The [Kamchatka Peninsula](/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula "Kamchatka Peninsula") in
the [Russian Far East](/wiki/Russian_Far_East "Russian Far East") is one of
the most various and active volcanic areas in the world,[51] with an area of
472,300 km2. It lies between the Pacific Ocean to the east and the [Okhotsk
Sea](/wiki/Okhotsk_Sea "Okhotsk Sea") to the west. Immediately offshore along
the Pacific coast of the peninsula runs the 10,500-m-deep [Kuril-Kamchatka
Trench](/wiki/Kuril-Kamchatka_Trench "Kuril-Kamchatka Trench"), where rapid
subduction of the Pacific Plate fuels the intense volcanism. Almost all types
of volcanic activity are present, from stratovolcanoes and shield volcanoes to
Hawaiian-style fissure eruptions.[51]

Over 30 active volcanoes and hundreds of [dormant](/wiki/Dormant_volcano
"Dormant volcano") and [extinct](/wiki/Extinct_volcano "Extinct volcano")
volcanoes are in two major volcanic belts. The most recent activity takes
place in the eastern belt,[51] starting in the north at the
[Shiveluch](/wiki/Shiveluch "Shiveluch") volcanic complex, which lies at the
junction of the [Aleutian](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands") and
Kamchatka volcanic arcs. Just to the south is the famous
[Klyuchi](/wiki/Klyuchi "Klyuchi") volcanic group, comprising the twin
volcanic cones of [Kliuchevskoi](/wiki/Kliuchevskoi "Kliuchevskoi") and
[Kamen](/wiki/Kamen_\(volcano\) "Kamen \(volcano\)"), the huge volcanic
complexes of [Tolbachik](/wiki/Tolbachik "Tolbachik") and
[Ushkovsky](/wiki/Ushkovsky "Ushkovsky"), and a number of other large
stratovolcanoes. The only active volcano in the central belt is found west of
here, the huge remote [Ichinsky](/wiki/Ichinsky "Ichinsky"). Farther south,
the eastern belt continues to the southern slope of Kamchatka, topped by loads
of [stratovolcanoes](/wiki/Stratovolcano "Stratovolcano"), continuing onto the
[Kuril Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands"), and southwards into
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan").

## Japan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Japan")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in Japan](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Japan
"List of volcanoes in Japan")

About 10% of the world's active volcanoes are found in Japan, which lies in a
zone of extreme crustal instability. They are formed by subduction of the
Pacific Plate and the [Philippine Sea Plate](/wiki/Philippine_Sea_Plate
"Philippine Sea Plate"). As many as 1,500 earthquakes are recorded yearly, and
magnitudes of 4 to 6 are not uncommon. Minor tremors occur almost daily in one
part of the country or another, causing some slight shaking of buildings.
Major earthquakes occur infrequently; the most famous in the 20th century
were: the [Great Kantō earthquake](/wiki/Great_Kant%C5%8D_earthquake "Great
Kantō earthquake") of 1923, in which 130,000 people died; and the [Great
Hanshin earthquake](/wiki/Great_Hanshin_earthquake "Great Hanshin earthquake")
of 17 January 1995, in which 6,434 people died. On March 11, 2011 [a magnitude
9.0 earthquake hit Japan](/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami "2011
Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami"), the country's biggest ever and the fifth
largest on record, according to US Geological Survey data.[52] Undersea
earthquakes also expose the Japanese coastline to danger from
[tsunamis](/wiki/Tsunami "Tsunami").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/FujiSunriseKawaguchiko2025WP.jpg/220px-
FujiSunriseKawaguchiko2025WP.jpg)](/wiki/File:FujiSunriseKawaguchiko2025WP.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FujiSunriseKawaguchiko2025WP.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mount Fuji](/wiki/Mount_Fuji "Mount Fuji") at sunrise from [Lake
Kawaguchi](/wiki/Lake_Kawaguchi "Lake Kawaguchi")

[Mount Bandai](/wiki/Mount_Bandai "Mount Bandai"), one of Japan's most noted
volcanoes, rises above the north shore of [Lake
Inawashiro](/wiki/Lake_Inawashiro "Lake Inawashiro"). Mount Bandai is formed
of several overlapping stratovolcanoes, the largest of which is O-Bandai
forming a [complex volcano](/wiki/Complex_volcano "Complex volcano"). O-Bandai
volcano was constructed within a horseshoe-shaped [caldera](/wiki/Caldera
"Caldera") that formed about 40,000 years when an earlier volcano collapsed,
forming the Okinajima debris avalanche, which traveled to the southwest and
was accompanied by a [plinian eruption](/wiki/Plinian_eruption "Plinian
eruption"). Four major [phreatic eruptions](/wiki/Phreatic_eruption "Phreatic
eruption") have occurred during the past 5,000 years, two of them in
historical time, in 806 and 1888. Seen from the south, Bandai presents a
conical profile, but much of the north side of the volcano is missing as a
result of the collapse of Ko-Bandai volcano during the 1888 eruption, in which
a debris avalanche buried several villages and formed several large lakes.

Nearly a century ago, the north flank of Mount Bandai collapsed during an
eruption quite similar to the May 18, 1980, eruption of Mount St. Helens.
After a week of seismic activity, a large earthquake on July 15, 1888, was
followed by a tremendous noise and a large explosion. Eyewitnesses heard about
15 to 20 additional explosions and observed that the last one was projected
almost horizontally to the north.

[Mount Fuji](/wiki/Mount_Fuji "Mount Fuji") is Japan's highest and most noted
volcano. The modern postglacial stratovolcano is constructed above a group of
overlapping volcanoes, remnants of which form irregularities on Fuji's
profile. Growth of the younger Mount Fuji began with a period of voluminous
lava flows from 11,000 to 8,000 years ago, accounting for four-fifths of the
volume of the younger Mount Fuji. Minor explosive eruptions dominated activity
from 8,000 to 4,500 years ago, with another period of major lava flows
occurring from 4,500 to 3,000 years ago. Subsequently, intermittent major
explosive eruptions occurred, with subordinate lava flows and small
pyroclastic flows. Summit eruptions dominated from 3,000 to 2,000 years ago,
after which flank vents were active. The extensive basaltic lava flows from
the summit and some of the more than 100 flank cones and vents blocked
drainage against the [Tertiary](/wiki/Tertiary "Tertiary") [Misaka
Mountains](/w/index.php?title=Misaka_Mountains&action=edit&redlink=1 "Misaka
Mountains \(page does not exist\)") on the north side of the volcano, forming
the [Fuji Five Lakes](/wiki/Fuji_Five_Lakes "Fuji Five Lakes"). The last
eruption of this dominantly basaltic volcano in 1707 ejected andesitic
[pumice](/wiki/Pumice "Pumice") and formed a large new crater on the east
flank. Some minor volcanic activity may occur in the next few years.

## Philippines[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Philippines")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in the
Philippines](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_the_Philippines "List of volcanoes in
the Philippines")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/MajorVolcanoesOfThePhilippines-
USGS.gif/170px-MajorVolcanoesOfThePhilippines-
USGS.gif)](/wiki/File:MajorVolcanoesOfThePhilippines-USGS.gif)

[](/wiki/File:MajorVolcanoesOfThePhilippines-USGS.gif "Enlarge")

Map showing major volcanoes of the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines
"Philippines")

The 1991 eruption of [Mount Pinatubo](/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo "Mount Pinatubo")
is the world's second-largest terrestrial eruption of the 20th century.
Successful predictions of the onset of the climactic eruption led to the
evacuation of tens of thousands of people from the surrounding areas, saving
many lives, but as the surrounding areas were severely damaged by pyroclastic
flows, ash deposits, and later, lahars caused by rainwater remobilising
earlier volcanic deposits, thousands of houses were destroyed.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Mayon1984.jpg/220px-
Mayon1984.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mayon1984.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mayon1984.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mayon Volcano](/wiki/Mayon_Volcano "Mayon Volcano") overlooks a pastoral
scene about five months before the volcano's violent eruption in September
1984.

[Mayon Volcano](/wiki/Mayon_Volcano "Mayon Volcano") is the Philippines' most
active volcano. It has steep upper slopes that average 35–40° and is capped by
a small summit crater. The historical eruptions of this basaltic-andesitic
volcano date back to 1616 and range from
[Strombolian](/wiki/Strombolian_eruption "Strombolian eruption") to basaltic
[Plinian eruptions](/wiki/Plinian_eruption "Plinian eruption"). Eruptions
occur predominately from the central conduit and have also produced lava flows
that travel far down the flanks. Pyroclastic flows and mudflows have commonly
swept down many of the roughly 40 ravines that radiate from the summit and
have often devastated populated lowland areas.

[Taal Volcano](/wiki/Taal_Volcano "Taal Volcano") has had 33 recorded
eruptions since 1572. A devastating eruption occurred in 1911, which claimed
more than a thousand lives. The deposits of that eruption consist of a
yellowish, fairly decomposed (nonjuvenile) [tephra](/wiki/Tephra "Tephra")
with a high sulfur content. The most recent period of activity lasted from
1965 to 1977, and was characterized by the interaction of magma with the lake
water, which produced violent phreatic and phreatomagmatic eruptions. Although
the volcano has been dormant since 1977, it has shown signs of unrest since
1991, with strong seismic activity and ground-fracturing events, as well as
the formation of small mud geysers on parts of the island.

[Kanlaon Volcano](/wiki/Kanlaon_Volcano "Kanlaon Volcano"), the most active
volcano in the central Philippines, has erupted 25 times since 1866. Eruptions
are typically phreatic explosions of small-to-moderate size that produce minor
ash falls near the volcano. On August 10, 1996, Kanlaon erupted without
warning, killing British student Julian Green and Filipinos Noel Tragico and
Neil Perez, who were among 24 mountain climbers who were trapped near the
summit.

## Indonesia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Indonesia")]

See also: [List of volcanoes in

Indonesia") and [2010 eruptions of Mount
Merapi](/wiki/2010_eruptions_of_Mount_Merapi "2010 eruptions of Mount Merapi")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Blethrow_merapi1.jpg/220px-
Blethrow_merapi1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blethrow_merapi1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Blethrow_merapi1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mount Merapi](/wiki/Mount_Merapi "Mount Merapi") in [Central
Java](/wiki/Central_Java "Central Java")

[![A chart with the heading "Major Volcanoes of Indonesia \(with eruptions
since 1900 A.D.\)". Depicted below the heading is an overhead view of a
cluster of
islands.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Map_indonesia_volcanoes.gif/220px-
Map_indonesia_volcanoes.gif)](/wiki/File:Map_indonesia_volcanoes.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Map_indonesia_volcanoes.gif "Enlarge")

Major volcanoes in Indonesia

The volcanoes in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia") are among the most
active of the Pacific Ring of Fire. They are formed due to subduction zones of
three main active tectonic plates namely the [Eurasian
Plate](/wiki/Eurasian_Plate "Eurasian Plate"), Pacific Plate, and [Indo-
Australian Plate](/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate "Indo-Australian Plate").[53]
Some of the volcanoes are notable for their eruptions, for instance,
[Krakatau](/wiki/Krakatau "Krakatau") for its global effects in 1883, [Lake
Toba](/wiki/Lake_Toba "Lake Toba") for its [supervolcanic](/wiki/Supervolcano
"Supervolcano") eruption estimated to have occurred 74,000 BP, which was
responsible for six years of [volcanic winter](/wiki/Volcanic_winter "Volcanic
winter"), and [Mount Tambora](/wiki/Mount_Tambora "Mount Tambora"), for the
most violent eruption in recorded history in 1815. The eruption of Mount
Tambora caused widespread harvest failures in Northern Europe, the
Northeastern United States, and eastern Canada in 1816, which was known as the
[Year Without a Summer](/wiki/Year_Without_a_Summer "Year Without a Summer").

The most active volcanoes are [Kelud](/wiki/Kelud "Kelud") and [Mount
Merapi](/wiki/Mount_Merapi "Mount Merapi") on [Java](/wiki/Java "Java")
island, which have been responsible for thousands of deaths in the region.
Since AD 1000, Kelud has erupted more than 30 times, of which the largest
eruption was at scale 5 on the [Volcanic Explosivity
Index](/wiki/Volcanic_Explosivity_Index "Volcanic Explosivity Index"), while
Merapi has erupted more than 80 times. The [International Association of
Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's
Interior](/wiki/International_Association_of_Volcanology_and_Chemistry_of_the_Earth%27s_Interior
"International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's
Interior") has named Merapi as a [Decade Volcano](/wiki/Decade_Volcano "Decade
Volcano") since 1995 because of its high volcanic activity. Another active
volcano is [Sinabung](/wiki/Sinabung "Sinabung") which erupted since 2013
until now.

"Edit section: New Zealand")]

Zealand](/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_New_Zealand "List of earthquakes in New
Zealand") and [Volcanism in New Zealand](/wiki/Volcanism_in_New_Zealand
"Volcanism in New Zealand")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Map_new_zealand_volcanoes.gif/220px-
Map_new_zealand_volcanoes.gif)](/wiki/File:Map_new_zealand_volcanoes.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Map_new_zealand_volcanoes.gif "Enlarge")

Major volcanoes of New Zealand

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Mt_Taranaki.JPG/220px-
Mt_Taranaki.JPG)](/wiki/File:Mt_Taranaki.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Mt_Taranaki.JPG "Enlarge")

View of Mount Taranaki from Stratford.

[GNS Science](/wiki/GNS_Science "GNS Science") was known as the Institute of
Geological and Nuclear Sciences from 1992 to 2005. GNS Science was partially
commercialised, and now operates as a government-owned company rather than as
a government department.

Originally part of the [Department of Scientific and Industrial
Research](/wiki/Department_of_Scientific_and_Industrial_Research_\(New_Zealand\)
"Department of Scientific and Industrial Research \(New Zealand\)") (DSIR), it
was established as an independent organisation when the Crown Research
Institutes were created in 1992.

As well as undertaking basic research, and operating the national geological
hazards monitoring network,[54] GNS Science is employed, both in New Zealand
and overseas, by various private groups (notably energy companies), as well as
central and local government agencies, to provide scientific advice and
information.[55]

GNS Science is based in [Avalon](/wiki/Avalon,_New_Zealand "Avalon, New
Zealand"), [Lower Hutt](/wiki/Lower_Hutt "Lower Hutt"), with facilities in
[Dunedin](/wiki/Dunedin "Dunedin") and [Wairakei](/wiki/Wairakei "Wairakei").

[New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") contains the world's strongest
concentration of youthful rhyolitic volcanoes, and voluminous sheets blanket
much of the [North Island](/wiki/North_Island "North Island"). The earliest
historically-dated eruption was at [Whakaari/White
Island](/wiki/Whakaari/White_Island "Whakaari/White Island") in 1826,[56]
followed in 1886 by the country's largest historical eruption at [Mount
Tarawera](/wiki/Mount_Tarawera "Mount Tarawera"). Much of the region north of
New Zealand's North Island is made up of [seamounts](/wiki/Seamount
"Seamount") and small islands, including 16 [submarine
volcanoes](/wiki/Submarine_volcano "Submarine volcano"). In the last 1.6
million years, most of New Zealand's volcanism is from the [Taupo Volcanic
Zone](/wiki/Taupo_Volcanic_Zone "Taupo Volcanic Zone").[57]

[Mount Ruapehu](/wiki/Mount_Ruapehu "Mount Ruapehu"), at the southern end of
the Taupo Volcanic Zone, is one of the most active volcanoes.[58] It began
erupting at least 250,000 years ago. In recorded history, major eruptions have
been about 50 years apart,[58] in 1895, 1945, and 1995–1996. Minor eruptions
are frequent, with at least 60 since 1945. Some of the minor eruptions in the
1970s generated small ash falls and lahars that damaged ski fields.[59]
Between major eruptions, a warm acidic crater lake forms, fed by melting snow.
Major eruptions may completely expel the lake water. Where a major eruption
has deposited a tephra dam across the lake's outlet, the dam may collapse
after the lake has refilled and risen above the level of its normal outlet,
the outrush of water causing a large lahar. The most notable lahar caused the
[Tangiwai disaster](/wiki/Tangiwai_disaster "Tangiwai disaster") on December
24, 1953, when 151 people aboard a Wellington to Auckland express train were
killed after the lahar destroyed the Tangiwai rail bridge just moments before
the train was due. In 2000, the [ERLAWS](/wiki/ERLAWS "ERLAWS") system was
installed on the mountain to detect such a collapse and alert the relevant
authorities.

The [Auckland volcanic field](/wiki/Auckland_volcanic_field "Auckland volcanic
field") on the North Island of New Zealand has produced a diverse array of
explosive craters, scoria cones, and lava flows. Currently
[dormant](/wiki/Dormant_volcano "Dormant volcano"), the field is likely to
erupt again with the next "hundreds to thousands of years", a very short
timeframe in geologic terms.[60] The field contains at least 40 volcanoes,
most recently active about 600 years ago at [Rangitoto
Island](/wiki/Rangitoto_Island "Rangitoto Island"), erupting 2.3 km3 of lava.

## Antarctica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ring_of_Fire&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Antarctica")]

Main article: [List of volcanoes in
Antarctica](/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Antarctica "List of volcanoes in
Antarctica")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mt_erebus.jpg/220px-
Mt_erebus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mt_erebus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mt_erebus.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mount Erebus](/wiki/Mount_Erebus "Mount Erebus"), 1972

The Pacific Ring of Fire is completed in the south by the continent of
[Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"),[61] which includes many large
volcanoes. The makeup and structure of the volcanoes in Antarctica change
largely from the other places around the ring. In contrast, the [Antarctic
Plate](/wiki/Antarctic_Plate "Antarctic Plate") is almost completely
surrounded by extensional zones, with several [mid-ocean ridges](/wiki/Mid-
ocean_ridge "Mid-ocean ridge") which encircle it, with only a small subduction
zone at the tip of the [Antarctic Peninsula](/wiki/Antarctic_Peninsula
"Antarctic Peninsula"), reaching eastward to the remote [South Sandwich
Islands](/wiki/South_Sandwich_Islands "South Sandwich Islands").[61] The most
well known volcano in Antarctica is [Mount Erebus](/wiki/Mount_Erebus "Mount
Erebus"), which is also the world's southernmost active volcano.[61] In many
respects the geology of the Antarctic Peninsula is an extension of the Andes,
hence the name sometimes used by geologists:
"[Antarctandes](/wiki/Antarctandes "Antarctandes")". At the opposite side of
the continent, the volcanoes of [Victoria Land](/wiki/Victoria_Land "Victoria
Land") may be seen as the 'other end' of the Antarctandes, thus completing the
Pacific Ring of Fire and continuing up through the [Balleny
Islands](/wiki/Balleny_Islands "Balleny Islands") to [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand").

Mount Erebus is the second-highest volcano in [Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica
"Antarctica") (after [Mount Sidley](/wiki/Mount_Sidley "Mount Sidley")) and
the southernmost active volcano on earth. It is the [sixth-
highest](/wiki/List_of_islands_by_highest_point "List of islands by highest
point") [ultra mountain](/wiki/Ultra_mountain "Ultra mountain") on an
island.[16] With a summit elevation of 3,794 m (12,448 ft), it is located on
[Ross Island](/wiki/Ross_Island "Ross Island"), which is also home to three
inactive volcanoes, [Mount Terror](/wiki/Mount_Terror_\(Antarctica\) "Mount
Terror \(Antarctica\)"), [Mount Bird](/wiki/Mount_Bird "Mount Bird"), and
[Mount Terra Nova](/wiki/Mount_Terra_Nova "Mount Terra Nova").

The volcano has been observed to be continuously active[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] since
1972 and is the site of the Mount Erebus Volcano Observatory run by the [New
Mexico Institute of Mining and
Technology](/wiki/New_Mexico_Institute_of_Mining_and_Technology "New Mexico
Institute of Mining and Technology").[62] Mount Erebus is currently the most
active volcano in Antarctica and is the current eruptive zone of the [Erebus
hotspot](/wiki/Erebus_hotspot "Erebus hotspot").

The volcanoes of the [Victoria Land](/wiki/Victoria_Land "Victoria Land") area
are the most well known in Antarctica,[61] most likely because they are the
most accessible. Much of Victoria Land is mountainous, developing the eastern
section of the [Transantarctic Mountains](/wiki/Transantarctic_Mountains
"Transantarctic Mountains"), and the several scattered volcanoes include
[Mount Overlord](/wiki/Mount_Overlord "Mount Overlord") and [Mount
Melbourne](/wiki/Mount_Melbourne "Mount Melbourne") in the northern part.[61]
Farther south are two more well-known volcanoes, [Mount
Discovery](/wiki/Mount_Discovery "Mount Discovery") and [Mount
Morning](/wiki/Mount_Morning "Mount Morning"), which are on the coast across
from Mount Erebus and Mount Terror on Ross Island. The volcanism in this area
is caused by rifting along a number of rift zones increasing mainly north-
south similar to the coast.[61]

[Marie Byrd Land](/wiki/Marie_Byrd_Land "Marie Byrd Land") contains the
largest volcanic region in Antarctica, covering a length of almost 600 mi (970
km) along the Pacific coast.[61] The volcanism is the result of rifting along
the vast [West Antarctic Rift](/wiki/West_Antarctic_Rift "West Antarctic
Rift"), which extends from the base of the Antarctic Peninsula to the
surrounding area of Ross Island, and the volcanoes are found along the
northern edge of the rift.[61] Protruding up through the ice are a large
number of major shield volcanoes, including Mount Sidley, which is the highest
volcano in Antarctica.[61] Although a number of the volcanoes are relatively
young and are potentially active ([Mount Berlin](/wiki/Mount_Berlin "Mount
Berlin"), [Mount Takahe](/wiki/Mount_Takahe "Mount Takahe"), [Mount
Waesche](/wiki/Mount_Waesche "Mount Waesche"), and [Mount
Siple](/wiki/Mount_Siple "Mount Siple")), others such as [Mount
Andrus](/wiki/Mount_Andrus "Mount Andrus") and [Mount
Hampton](/wiki/Mount_Hampton "Mount Hampton") are over 10 million years old,
yet maintain uneroded constructional forms.[61] The desert-like surroundings
of the Antarctic interior, along with a very thick and stable ice sheet which
encloses and protects the bases of the volcanoes, which decreases the speed of
erosion by an issue of perhaps a thousand relative to volcanoes in moist
temperate or tropical climates.
